title: Particulate Matter Levels in Air Exceed WHO Limits in Majority of World's Big Cities
summary: New Delhi faces dangerous air quality levels with AQI reaching 424, far exceeding WHO safety standards. The severe plus smog conditions in India's capital highlight the growing global crisis of urban air pollution, particularly regarding particulate matter concentrations.
content:
People in New Delhi are facing hazardous air quality conditions as severe plus smog blankets India's capital city. On November 15, the National Capital Region's Air Quality Index (AQI) reached a dangerous level of 424, according to measurements from the Central Pollution Control Board.

For context, an AQI reading below 50 indicates good air quality, while readings above 300 signal hazardous conditions that pose serious health risks to residents. The current levels far exceed safety standards set by the World Health Organization (WHO).

The severe smog situation in New Delhi exemplifies a wider problem facing major metropolitan areas worldwide, where particulate matter concentrations frequently surpass recommended limits, threatening public health.

## Air Quality Crisis in New Delhi

People in New Delhi are facing hazardous air quality conditions as severe plus smog blankets India's capital city. On November 15, the National Capital Region's Air Quality Index (AQI) reached a dangerous level of 424, according to measurements from the Central Pollution Control Board.

For context, an AQI reading below 50 indicates good air quality, while readings above 300 signal hazardous conditions that pose serious health risks to residents. The current levels far exceed safety standards set by the World Health Organization (WHO).

The severe smog situation in New Delhi exemplifies a wider problem facing major metropolitan areas worldwide, where particulate matter concentrations frequently surpass recommended limits, threatening public health.
